headline: Late-Summer Mixed-Fruit Pie Recipe
description: Whether you choose my blend or your own, the filling bakes up sweet-tart and a little jammy under a golden, flaky crust.

video.description: No fancy ingredients, no special equipment, no frozen butter or ice water; just the flakiest, most buttery (not to mention sturdy and easy to handle) pie crust imaginable. [Video: Natalie Holt. Technique and onscreen demo: Stella Parks]
video.name: How to Make an Old-Fashioned All-Butter Pie Crust

name: Late-Summer Mixed-Fruit Pie Recipe
recipeIngredient: 3 medium plums, apricots, or nectarines (about 12 ounces; 340g)
9 ounces pitted cherries (1 2/3 heaping cups; 255g), from about 12 ounces whole fruit (2 1/4 heaping cups; 340g)
6 ounces fresh blueberries, blackberries, or raspberries (1 cup; 170g)
4 ounces Cape gooseberries, currants, or fresh cranberries (1/2 cup; 110g)
1/2 teaspoon (2g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt; for table salt, use half as much by volume or use the same weight
1 1/2 ounces tapioca starch (1/3 cup plus 1 teaspoon; 40g), such as Bob's Red Mill (see note)
Old-Fashioned Flaky Pie Dough , rolled and chilled as per the directions for a double crust
1/8 teaspoon (1/2g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt; for table salt, use half as much by volume or use the same weight

recipeInstructions.text: For the Filling (see notes): Wash plums (no need to peel), cut into 1/2-inch slices, and measure out 9 ounces (1 1/2 cups; 255g) in a large bowl. Add pitted cherries, blueberries, and Cape gooseberries, or whatever mix of fruit you prefer, to bring the total weight to 28 ounces (790g; volume will vary). Toss with sugar, salt, and tapioca starch, folding with a flexible spatula until well combined. Scrape into prepared pie shell and top with remaining dough, as a solid sheet, a lattice , a herringbone , or checkerboard. Trim away excess dough and refrigerate to ensure top crust is completely chilled, about 30 minutes. Meanwhile, adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 400°F (205°C).

For the Egg Wash (if using): Whisk egg, egg yolk, cream, and salt in a small bowl. Brush over chilled top crust in a thin, even layer. This will give the crust a glossy, golden sheen, but is not necessary in any way.

Place chilled pie on a parchment-lined rimmed baking sheet. Bake until crust is golden, about 1 hour, then loosely cover with tented foil. (Alternatively, an empty baking sheet can be placed on topmost rack of oven to serve as a shield.) Continue baking until filling is bubbling even in the very center of the pie, about 15 minutes more. If crust completely covers filling, bake until pie reaches an internal temperature of 212°F (100°C) on a digital thermometer.

To Serve: Cool pie until center of filling is no warmer than 85°F (29°C) on a digital thermometer, about 3 hours depending on the type of pie plate. (Above that temperature, filling will be runny and thin.) Slice into wedges with a sharp knife, pressing firmly against bottom and sides of pie plate to ensure under-crust is completely cut. Wrapped in foil, leftovers will keep up to 3 days at room temperature; warm 10 minutes in a 350°F (175°C) oven to revive crust before serving.

review.reviewBody: I love this pie so much. It's not too sweet and when using the old fashioned flaky pie dough, it's a classic. The dough lives up to its name, shatteringly flaky. It's always a treat when i can find gooseberries but when I can't, i sub in raspberries, still giving the pie a tart component. I make this multiple times a summer and its always a crowd (or solo) pleaser.
hey @Stellaparks I was wondering if I could add fruits such as pears, apples, and the such. Thanks, the recipe looks promising!

If I'm having trouble finding gooseberries, fresh cranberries or currants (which I'm assuming are dried but still have no luck finding them) is there another high pectin fruit that can be substituted? Or is it ok to just add an extra 4oz of fruit to the one of the other fruit categories in the pie?

@Yael, the ingredients list provides the weights of the whole fruit for the purpose of grocery shopping, but in step 1 the pitted/prepared fruit is still measured out to 28 ounces. I find that with soft fruit like peaches and plums, the 75 minute bake-time needed to crisp the bottom crust can really do a whammy on the fruit's texture; it's still thick enough to slice, but on the mushier/jammier end of the spectrum. It's not a bad thing when that fruit represents a fraction of the whole, but I don't enjoy it when it's 100%. If you want a bottom crust for the crumble, I wouldn't change anything about the baking time or temp, but I would wait about 25 min or so before adding the topping. If you don't want a bottom crust, then I'd recommend using my blackberry cobbler or rhubarb crisp as a template.

Hello!
I was thinking of making a plum pie this coming week (have a bunch of several varieties of plums that need using up), so read this recipe as well as the cherry pie recipe in your book, and something is bit confusing - the basic fruit/sugar/tapioca formula in your book appears to be 28/7/1.5 oz, but unless something is very wrong with my math, this recipe here has 31 total oz of fruit instead of 28. Is this because you're using a variety of fruit, rather than just cherries? Which amount should I aim for?
And also, *would* this even work as an all-plum pie? In the book you mention peaches as being too soft to survive the longer bake of a pie, wondering if this is true for plums as well... there *is* a comment here about using this for apricot-peach, so I'm hopeful, but would like to make sure.
And what if I were to make a crumble top, instead of a solid crust? How would that change the baking time, if at all? (There is a recipe for a plum crumble pie elsewhere on the site, and I suppose I might make that, but I trust your formula...)

Sorry that I have so many questions!
(On a different note, I've now written "plum" so many times that the word has begun to look deeply weird.)
